text: Kappa B - specific DNA binding proteins are differentially inhibited by enhancer mutations and biological oxidation .

Kappa B ( kappa B ) enhancer binding proteins isolated from the nuclei of activated human T cells produce two distinct nucleoprotein complexes when incubated with the kappa B element from the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 receptor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2R alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) gene .

These two DNA - protein complexes are composed of at least four host proteins ( <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p55 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p75 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> p85 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , each of which shares structural similarity with the <extra_id_0> v-rel <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> oncogene product .

Nuclear expression of these proteins is induced with distinctly biphasic kinetics following phorbol ester activation of T cells ( <extra_id_0> p55 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p75 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> early and <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / <extra_id_0> p85 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> late ) .

text: DNA binding by all four of these Rel-related factors is blocked by selective chemical modification of lysine and arginine residues , suggesting that both of these basic amino acids are required for binding to the kappa B element .
Similarly , covalent modification of free sulfhydryl groups with diamide ( reversible ) or N - ethylmaleimide ( irreversible ) results in a complete loss of DNA binding activity .

In contrast , mild oxidation with <extra_id_0> glucose oxidase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> selectively inhibits <extra_id_0> p75 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p85 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binding while not blocking <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p55 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> interactions .

text: These findings suggest that reduced cysteine thiols play an important role in the DNA binding activity of this family of Rel-related transcription factors .
